'''''Agaricus lilaceps''''', also known as the '''cypress Agaricus''' or the '''giant cypress agaricus''' is a species of mushroom. It is among the largest and most edible ''Agaricus'' species in California.<ref>Kerrigan, Richard W. (1986). The Agaricales (Gilled Fungi) of California. 6. Agaricaceae. Mad River Press: Eureka, CA. page 62</ref> Aside from size, ''Agaricus lilaceps'' is characterized by a robust stature, as the stipe often club-shaped.<ref name=Kerrigan1985>Kerrigan, R. W. (1985). Studies in ''Agaricus'' II: ''Agaricus lilaceps'' re-evaluated. ''[[Mycologia]]'' '''77''': 137–141.</ref>

== Description ==

The [[Pileus (mycology)|cap]] of the mushroom is 8–20 cm broad, convex, and expands to nearly plane. As it ages, the disc sometimes depresses. The margin, however, is incurved, although it decurves at maturity. The surface of the cap is at first pallid to cream-buff, especially when developing below ground, but soon becomes appressed and fibrillose-squamose. In addition, it varies from brown, hazel-brown, dull chestnut-brown, and occasionally lilac-brown, although it darkens as it ages. At times, the surface develops orange-brown, rufescent areas. The context is thick, very firm, white, and slowly turns [[wine (color)|vinaceous]] when cut or bruised. The  odor is that of a typical mushroom, although it tastes mild.<ref>Hotson, J. W. & [[Daniel Elliot Stuntz|D. E. Stuntz]] (1938). The genus ''Agaricus'' in western Washington. ''Mycologia'' '''30''': 204–234.</ref>

The [[Lamella (mycology)|gills]] of ''Agaricus lilaceps'' are free, close, moderately broad, and dingy-pink when young. However, when bruised, it turns reddish-brown slowly, and dark chocolate-brown at maturity.<ref>Kerrigan, R. W., P. Callac, M. P. Challen & L. A. Parra (2005). ''Agaricus'' section Xanthodermatei: a phylogenetic reconstruction with commentary on taxa. ''Mycologia'' '''97''': 1292–1315.</ref>

The [[Stipe (mycology)|stipe]] is 9–19 cm long, 3–5 cm thick, and equal to [[clavate]]. The core of the stem is stuffed, while the surface is dry and white with scattered [[fibrils]] at the apex. However, the base is a discoloring dingy brownish-red to ochraceous. Also, the stipe can be smooth to patchy fibrillose below.<ref>Zeller, S.M. (1938). New or Noteworthy Agarics from the Pacific Coast States. ''Mycologia'' '''30''': 468–474.</ref> There is a partial white veil that is membranous, thick, and elastic. The upper surface is wrinkled, while the lower surface is more or less smooth, occasionally cracking and forming patches. Also, the lower surface sometimes yellows in age or when bruised, forming a superior, pendulous annulus at maturity. The stipe gradually becomes blackish from adhering spores.<ref name=Kerrigan1985/>

The [[spore]]s are 5–6.5 by 4–5 μm, elliptical, and smooth. The [[spore print]] is dark-brown.

== Habitat ==

''Agaricus lilaceps'' are scattered or clustered under [[Monterey Cypress]] (''Cupressus macrocarpa''). They fruit from mid to late [[winter]].<ref>Arora, D. (1986). ''Mushrooms demystified: A comprehensive guide to the fleshy fungi''. Berkeley: Ten Speed Press. 959 pp.</ref> They are found exclusively in the central area of [[California]], though ''A. lilaceps'' can be found in the west in the [[Monterey Bay]] area. In addition, ''A. lilaceps'' can  also be found on [[Stanford University]] under the [[eucalyptus]].<ref name=Kerrigan1985/><ref>Smith, A. H. (1940). Studies in the genus ''Agaricus''. ''Papers of the Michigan Academy of Science'' '''24''': 107–138.</ref><ref>http://www.mykoweb.com/CAF/species/Agaricus_lilaceps.html</ref>
